examples.sentence: 〜てほしい (te-hoshii) - Want someone to do

sections.heading: What is 〜たい (tai)?
sections.content:
〜たい expresses the speaker's desire to do something. It means "want to (do)" and is primarily used for first-person statements about your own wishes.

[Verb stem] + たい 食べたい "want to eat" 行きたい "want to go"

children.heading: Basic Pattern
children.content: Verb (masu-stem) + たい Plain: 〜たい Polite: 〜たいです 食べる → 食べます → 食べたい / 食べたいです "want to eat" 行く → 行きます → 行きたい / 行きたいです "want to go"

children.heading: Finding the Verb Stem
children.content:
Remove ます from the masu-form:

食べます → 食べ → 食べたい 読みます → 読み → 読みたい 見ます → 見 → 見たい 来ます → 来 → 来たい します → し → したい

children.heading: First Person (I want to)
children.content:
Primarily used for speaker's own desires.

日本に行きたい "I want to go to Japan" 寿司を食べたい "I want to eat sushi" 日本語を勉強したい "I want to study Japanese" 映画を見たい "I want to watch a movie"

sections.heading: Conjugation Like I-adjectives
sections.content: たい conjugates like an i-adjective, not a verb.

children.heading: Present Affirmative
children.content: 食べたい / 食べたいです "want to eat" 行きたい / 行きたいです "want to go"

children.heading: Present Negative
children.content: 食べたくない / 食べたくないです "don't want to eat" 行きたくない / 行きたくないです "don't want to go"

children.heading: Past Affirmative
children.content: 食べたかった / 食べたかったです "wanted to eat" 行きたかった / 行きたかったです "wanted to go"

children.heading: Past Negative
children.content: 食べたくなかった / 食べたくなかったです "didn't want to eat" 行きたくなかった / 行きたくなかったです "didn't want to go"

children.heading: が or を with Object
children.content:
With たい, you can use either が or を for the object:

寿司が食べたい ✓ 寿司を食べたい ✓ "I want to eat sushi" 映画が見たい ✓ 映画を見たい ✓ "I want to watch a movie"

Note: が emphasizes the object more, を is more neutral. が is slightly more common with たい.

children.heading: Direct Questions (for asking others)
children.content: 何が食べたい？ "What do you want to eat?" どこに行きたい？ "Where do you want to go?" 何をしたいですか？ "What do you want to do?"

children.heading: About Third Person
children.content:
Use たがる instead (covered in next article):

Less natural: 彼は何が食べたい？ ⚠️ Better: 彼は何を食べたがっている？ ✓ "What does he want to eat?"

children.heading: 〜たいと思う (I think I want to)
children.content:
Softens the statement.

日本に行きたいと思います "I think I want to go to Japan" 映画を見たいと思う "I think I want to watch a movie"

children.heading: 〜たいんです (explanatory)
children.content:
Explains your desire.

日本に行きたいんです "The thing is, I want to go to Japan" 質問したいんですが "I want to ask a question (and...)"

children.heading: 〜たくて (because I want to)
children.content:
Te-form for reason.

日本に行きたくて、貯金している "Because I want to go to Japan, I'm saving money" 会いたくて、来ました "Because I wanted to see you, I came"

children.heading: とても/すごく〜たい (really want to)
children.content:
Emphasizing strong desire.

とても食べたい "really want to eat" すごく会いたい "really want to meet" めちゃくちゃ行きたい "really, really want to go"

children.heading: Casual
children.content: 行きたい "I want to go" 食べたくない "I don't want to eat"

children.heading: Polite
children.content: 行きたいです "I want to go" 食べたくないです / 食べたくありません "I don't want to eat"

children.heading: Daily Activities
children.content: 食べたい - want to eat 飲みたい - want to drink 寝たい - want to sleep 休みたい - want to rest 遊びたい - want to play

children.heading: Movement
children.content: 行きたい - want to go 来たい - want to come 帰りたい - want to go home/return 出かけたい - want to go out 旅行したい - want to travel

children.heading: Communication
children.content: 話したい - want to talk 聞きたい - want to listen/ask 見たい - want to see/watch 会いたい - want to meet 知りたい - want to know

children.heading: Activities
children.content: 勉強したい - want to study 働きたい - want to work 買いたい - want to buy 作りたい - want to make 読みたい - want to read

children.heading: Example 1: Making Plans
children.content: A: 今日、何がしたい？ "What do you want to do today?" B: 映画を見たい "I want to watch a movie" A: いいね！何が見たい？ "Nice! What do you want to watch?" B: アクション映画が見たい "I want to watch an action movie"

children.heading: Example 2: Lunch Decision
children.content: A: お昼、何が食べたい？ "What do you want to eat for lunch?" B: ラーメンが食べたいな "I want to eat ramen" A: 私も！どこに行く？ "Me too! Where should we go?"

children.heading: Example 3: Future Plans
children.content: A: 将来、何がしたい？ "What do you want to do in the future?" B: 日本で働きたいです "I want to work in Japan" A: いいね！頑張ってね "Nice! Do your best"

children.heading: Mistake 1: Using たい for others' desires directly
children.content: Less natural: 彼は行きたい ⚠️ Better: 彼は行きたがっている ✓ "He wants to go" Or in questions: Natural: 行きたい？ ✓ (to the person directly) "Do you want to go?"

children.heading: Mistake 2: Wrong conjugation
children.content: Wrong: 食べたくないかった ❌ Right: 食べたくなかった ✓ "didn't want to eat"

children.heading: Mistake 3: Using masu-form
children.content: Wrong: 食べますたい ❌ Right: 食べたい ✓ "want to eat"

children.heading: Mistake 4: Adding です to casual forms incorrectly
children.content: Wrong: 食べたかったです ⚠️ (should be) Right: 食べたかったです ✓ "wanted to eat" Note: Both forms exist, but check your entire sentence's politeness level

children.heading: 〜たいものだ (really want to)
children.content:
Expresses strong wish.

一度行ってみたいものだ "I really want to try going once" 会いたいものだ "I really want to meet (them)"

children.heading: 〜たいところだ (would like to)
children.content:
Polite way to express desire.

行きたいところです "I would like to go" お願いしたいところです "I would like to ask (a favor)"

children.heading: 〜たいと思っている (have been wanting to)
children.content:
Ongoing desire.

ずっと行きたいと思っている "I've been wanting to go for a long time" 前から会いたいと思っていました "I've been wanting to meet you"

children.heading: Intensifiers
children.content: とても行きたい "really want to go" すごく食べたい "really want to eat" めちゃくちゃ会いたい "really, really want to meet" どうしても行きたい "want to go no matter what"

children.heading: Don't Want To
children.content: 行きたくない "don't want to go" 食べたくない "don't want to eat" 勉強したくない "don't want to study" 働きたくない "don't want to work"

children.heading: 〜たかったら (if you want to)
children.content: 行きたかったら、一緒に行こう "If you want to go, let's go together" 食べたかったら、どうぞ "If you want to eat, please do"

children.heading: 〜たければ (if you want to)
children.content: 行きたければ、行ってもいい "If you want to go, you may go" 見たければ、見せます "If you want to see, I'll show you"

children.heading: Indirect Expression
children.content:
Japanese often uses たい with と思う to sound less direct:

Direct: 行きたい "I want to go" Softer: 行きたいと思います "I think I want to go"

children.heading: In Questions
children.content:
When asking about others' desires directly (second person), たい is natural:

何が食べたい？ ✓ "What do you want to eat?" どこに行きたい？ ✓ "Where do you want to go?"

children.heading: Basic Desires
children.content: 日本に行きたい "I want to go to Japan" 寿司が食べたい "I want to eat sushi" 友達に会いたい "I want to meet my friend" 映画を見たい "I want to watch a movie"

children.heading: Negative
children.content: 今日は出かけたくない "I don't want to go out today" 勉強したくない "I don't want to study" 働きたくない "I don't want to work"

children.heading: Past
children.content: 昨日、寝たかった "I wanted to sleep yesterday" 日本に行きたかった "I wanted to go to Japan" もっと勉強したかった "I wanted to study more"

children.heading: With Reasons
children.content: 疲れたから、休みたい "Because I'm tired, I want to rest" 日本語を勉強したくて、日本に来た "Because I wanted to study Japanese, I came to Japan" 会いたくて、電話した "Because I wanted to see you, I called"

children.heading: Questions
children.content: 何がしたいですか？ "What do you want to do?" どこに行きたい？ "Where do you want to go?" 何を食べたい？ "What do you want to eat?" いつ会いたい？ "When do you want to meet?"

sections.heading: Related Grammar Points
sections.content: 〜たがる (tagaru) - Want to (3rd person) 〜ほしい (hoshii) - Want something 〜てほしい (te-hoshii) - Want someone to do I-adjective Conjugation - Similar conjugation pattern 〜たいと思う - Softening expressions Desire Expressions - Overview of want/desire
